etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Philemon Holland (1552–1637), translator. From post-classical Latin callitriche (Colonna 1616; subsequently adopted in scientific Latin as a genus name (LinnaeusSpecies plantarum II. 969), specifically use of classical Latin callitriche, ablative of callithrix waterwort (Pliny) from ancient Greek καλλίθριξ beautiful-haired

definitions: A water starwort; a plant of the genus Callitriche. Also (in form Callitriche): the genus itself.
